title: From Roy Rogers to Lil Nas X: The Wild Western Story of Nudie Suits
text:
Since 2001, Jerry Lee Atwood, a custom tailor in Indianapolis, has specialized in spangled, heavily embroidered suits, typically created for country singers like Nikki Lane and Joshua Hedley. A year and a half ago, however, Mr. Atwood got an Instagram message from a celebrity stylist proposing a new kind of client: specifically, Post Malone, a 24-year-old rapper with face tattoos. Mr. Atwood was unsure—he didn’t know who Post Malone was. As he searched YouTube, up popped a video of the rapper with about 300 million views. “I was like, ‘This is obviously somebody that I needed to pay attention to,’” said Mr. Atwood who runs his label Union Western with co-designer Joe Walters.

Mr. Atwood got to work and, in October 2018, Mr. Malone sauntered down the red carpet at the American Music Awards in Los Angeles in Union Western’s creation: a teal blue suit with leopard-spotted snakes crawling up the sides and rhinestones embellishments stretching down the legs.

A year later, fashion is still bullish on embellishment. And sensational embroidered suits, of the kind that Gene Autry once wore, are having a renaissance. At MTV’s Video Music Awards last month in Newark, N.J., the electronic artist Diplo wore a suit slathered with decorative mushrooms and psychotropic chemical compounds, while “Old Town Road” rapper Lil Nas X donned a cherry-red number embroidered with bucking broncos and mystical “third eyes.” They were made, respectively, by Fort Lonesome, a 9-year-old Austin, Tex.-based outfit and Union Western. These two labels, along with Rose Cuts of Los Angeles, are resurrecting the so-called “Nudie suit” for a contemporary clientele.

Share Your Thoughts What do you think of this style of suits? Must have or pass, and why? Join the conversation below.

The original Nudie was Nudie Cohn, an Eastern European immigrant who whipped up heavily embroidered “western” suits in the early-to-mid 20th century. Following in the footsteps of earlier western tailors Nathan Turk and Bernard Lichtenstein (known as Rodeo Ben), Mr. Cohn opened shop in Hollywood, Calif., in the late 1940s. “Nudie became really the most well-known of them because he was very outgoing. He really knew how to market himself,” said Holly George-Warren, a music writer who is working on a documentary about Mr. Cohn’s life called “Rhinestone Cowboy,” set to be released next year. He drove a custom Pontiac Bonneville with “Nudie” emblazoned on the spare tire rack, attended concerts in his spotlight-stealing suits and designed countless outfits for some of music’s biggest names.

Initially, “Nudie suits” (as any suit of this style would come to be called) were donned by country kingpins like Roy Rogers and Hank Williams Sr., but the appeal crossed genres. Elton John wore a rose-embroidered suit on the cover of his 1972 single “Rocket Man.” Jerry Garcia wore a skeleton-embroidered blazer while performing in 1973. And Sly Stone sported a rhinestone studded get-up on the “Mike Douglas Show” in 1974. “What would happen is the look would start dying out among one [genre] group and then another group would take it up,” explained Ms. George-Warren.

Nudie Cohn didn’t invent embroidered westernwear, but through his masterful marketing, the suits came to be associated with his name. Here he is around 1964 with singer Jimmy Dean. Photo: Getty Images

Mr. Cohn died in 1984, but his aesthetic endures. “The whole idea of customizing your clothes in general is really popular right now,” said Judith Pierce, the 29-year-old owner of Rose Cut Clothing. In the world of personalized clothes, a custom Nudie suit is about as personal as it gets, allowing a customer to not only pick out the fabric and shape, but specify which characters and slogans get stitched across it as well.

Each suit reflects the customer’s specific tastes and demands. Ms. Pierce often applies customer’s zodiac signs or a favorite animal onto the suits she designs. About 40% of her business consists of non-famous, yet eccentric, folks who want something special for their wedding.

The other 60% of Ms. Pierce’s customer base are musicians or performers, reflecting the music world’s decades-long love affair with Nudie suits. “There’s a very symbiotic relationship between flashy clothing and people who perform on stage,” said Kathie Sever, the owner of Fort Lonesome, who has been making embroidered western wear for about 20 years. As Joe Walters, the other half of Union Western, explained, “the flashy embellished western wear that Nudie and Turk made is the original bling,” which might explain its appeal to cocksure rappers like Lil Nas X and Post Malone.

Rose Cut, a Los Angeles based outfit, is one of a few upstart westernwear companies that have thrust Nudie suits back into the limelight.

Today, these far-out suits have a potent psychedelic appeal. “What is happening right now is informed far more by a Gram Parsons vibe than….a Roy Rogers vibe,” said Ms. Sever, referring to the notorious suit embroidered with a marijuana leaf that country singer Gram Parsons wore on the cover of the Flying Burrito Brothers’ 1969 album “The Gilded Palace of Sin.” The suit Fort Lonesome made for Diplo, stitched with the chemical compounds of drugs like DMT and MDMA, and “LSD” embroidered down the sleeves, could be seen as the descendant of Mr. Parsons’s outfit.
description: Heavily embroidered ‘Nudie’ suits, a favorite of Gene Autry and singing cowboys, have again found an audience with bold grooms and rappers like Lil Nas X and Post Malone.
